description: Nutella latte!!! Mmmm. Everyone that works here is considerate ans knowledgeable. The drinks are delicious and the prices aren't outrageous.
author: Michelle P.

description:
Captive audience? Let's price gouge them and give them lousy food and service because we can!

Mediocre coffee.

Full of lawyers, cops, and those doing jury duty due to the convenience factor.
author: Chuck G.

description: The area doesn't have much cafes across the courthouse. Got a "matcha green tea latte", but I don't think the guy that was making it knew what it really was. Instead, I was given sweeten green tea with more sugar and milk. Quite disappointed as I wanted matcha, but I had to rush back for jury duty.
author: Mandy D.

description: Green omelette was pretty good.  A little expensive but average for an SF cafe.  Lots of police officers and lawyers in suits. Not a secret find but not bad either if you are summoned for jury duty.  Roast their own coffee too with light and dark roasts.
author: Michael H.

description:
One of the few places to eat near the Hall of Justice.

Egg dishes are skimpy, kind of awful, and grossly overpriced. Why do they bother? It's so easy to deliver good value in scrambled eggs.

I gather sandwiches are the thing to get here. But there's a smaller, less fancy place down the street that looks more promising.
author: Crabcakes C.

description:
Called for jury duty-- this is directly across courthouse.  Long line... and once I finally get to front?  I'm told coffee orders are taken at register (by an unfriendly female) no apology to me for ata ding in long line needlessly... ok

Then I get to register where I place my order.  Someone right behind me also ordered only coffee --- and the person at the register then informs HER (in Spanish) the she didn't need to wait next time and use the coffee only line.  The same was not said to me.  Did he assume I don't speak Spanish??  So then I said-- "why didn't you tell me that?" And he was so shocked I knew what he has said he shrugged his shoulders and played dumb.  

Walk further and find a Starbucks.   Besides .. the sandwiches didn't look good at all.
author: Kelly C.

description: Walked in no warm greeting at all asked for a medium coffee and a croissant no more asked for a bagel no more bagel then this guy behind the counter says you have to come earlier it about 9:30 when I came in not nice at all asked for the password to the free WiFi gave me wrong one it looks like they get a lot of customers from the court house across the street and all the bail bonds next door these people really don't have a choice but to come here they are RUDE, don't have any breakfast stuff over priced the reason I gave 1 Star the coffee was ok
author: sandra j.

description:
I'm sitting in court for jury duty, the clock strikes 12, and the judge dismisses us for an hour and 30 minutes of lunch break. Where to go now? I knew I passed by a Subway right outside to the left and I knew there were a bunch of bail bonds right across the way. Just a bit towards the right (across the street) was Caffe Roma!

Thank God I found this place. The atmosphere was perfect. I ordered a Fettuccini Chicken Pesto pasta which turned out to be 13.50$. It was a good portion size and it was delicious and pesto-y but I wish it had a side of bread. I also decided to get something from their baked goods section near the checkout, a lemon lavender gluten free cookie, which was great until I checked the expiration date which was 2 months old. 

The service was nice. They also offered a different baked good or my money back. (Thank you)
author: Liza H.

description: Grabbed a tea here, which consisted of a tiny tea bag in hot water. Far worse than Starbucks. Not sure why their tea costs more than their coffee, which clearly costs more to make. Cafe Roma needs to up it's tea game.
author: Nick C.

description: The Penne Pasta with Beef Bolognese was way better then I was expecting from a small Cafe next to the court building. I'd definitely go back just for that.
author: Jason S.

description: The coffee is not so great here. Too bad--it's your only real option near the courthouse.
author: M G.

description: The place is extremely over priced and the food is mediocre. The service is not great either. There is another cafe down the street with much better food, service, and it is much cheaper
author: Joaquin D.

description:
I love the way my clothes smell after leaving a coffee shop. Brings me back to the days of my barista career in college. Today I got that smell to stick to me for the better half of the afternoon. Why do I like Caffe Roma? Well, free Wi-Fi, super nice staff, food, and java java java! 

While on jury duty, one can begin to get a tad weary of the minute details of certain events that cannot be lamented to anyone during the trial, so to prevent my head from jerking awake during the sometimes dense cross examination, I rely on the smooth in house roasted coffee stylings of Caffe Roma to help get me through the more dense aspects of the trial. 

A small hot cup is like $1.85, which is good compared to anywhere else in the nearby area, trust me, I checked. I may get lunch as the food looks pretty decent, too. And there you have it.
author: Crystal C.

description:
I can't quite figure this place out.  

It's part wi-fi cafe, part Italian restaurant, part coffee-bar, part pastry shop, and part meeting room. Most importantly though: it's one block from where I work. At this point, I've probably eaten there 10+ times. 

So what's good: 
-- Crab cakes (I know, odd mix of stuff sold here)
-- Homemade cookies
-- Sandwiches! 
-- Pasta with tomato-based sauces (Pesto smelled funky)
-- Fruit Salad

What's not as good: 
-- The Cannoli (sad day for this Italian girl), but they're way too sweet and they don't taste like ricotta
-- Ceasar dressing (ew - dunno what happened there)

One of the best things this place has going for it is the staff. There's a smiling older man who always gets my order started and the other servers are super fast and will customize your meal however you want. 

It's a pretty quick in-and-out lunch, I always bring food back to the office, and they make sure I have utensils/napkints/etc. 


My verdict? Good when you're looking for food and a mild walk, but not a destination.
author: Andrea D.

description:
Directly across the street from Hall of Justice. 

I dropped in this morning prior to going to Traffic Court to see about a citation.

I looked at the glass display case.  Bagels, pastries, loaf cakes.  The counter guy suggested the raspberry swirl crumb coffee cake so I went with that with a caffe latte. 

The coffee cake was good even though I'm sure it wasn't made the same day as the crumbs were crumbs no more.  

They offer a full breakfast & lunch menu.  

Lots of tables and chairs.
author: Shirley N.

description: Their egg and cheese bagel didn't have as much egg as other places probably would (seemed like one egg instead of two?) but otherwise it was fine. Four stars though because they make a decent latte and don't charge extra for almond milk. $3.25 for a 12 oz and $3.50 for a 16 oz latte is a deal in SF.
author: Will H.

description:
Worst customer service ever, after buying coffee and pastry, I politely asked for some tap water, the barista gave me a nasty look and said nothing, so I asked another barista politely, and he said in a condescending manner, "she (the other barista) didn't give it to you?", I said no, then he said, "you'll have to wait." So I finished my food and it took about 20min and the water never came.

The coffee and pastry was mediocre (2.5 star).

I usually leave reviews only for places I love, this is a first.
author: Jane Xiaojing G.

description: I was on jury duty and discovered Caffe Roma (it wasn't hard, it's right across the street from the Hall of Justice). I wouldn't go out of my way to re-visit, but it was a great place to stop by for lunch while I was in the area. The menu is big and a little confusing - but the advantage is that you'll definitely find something you like! Food was good, but again, nothing super duper memorable.
author: Connie Q.

description:
I came here for a coffee during a short break while on jury duty. Clean and spacious, across the street from the SF court house. The coffee is great, service is fast. Didn't eat any food. 

$5 minimum for credit cards.
author: Vivek R.

description: Don't leave San Francisco without having their lobster tail pastries, (Sfogliatelle). They are off the chain good. The Tiramisu was creamy and very well done as well. So glad we found this place.
author: Sam S.

description: Eh. An affordable (large coffee for under $2.50) coffee shop in soma. A great place to stop if you're at court/jury duty. Otherwise, the coffee is a bit burnt tasting and mediocre.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
The food there is good and the people are nice!
One day, they had a new cook in the kitchen (and he was alone). Disorganization slowed everything down, but the owner graciously offered me and my coworkers desert: delicious tiramisu!
I recommend their pasta of course.
author: Julien A.

description: A nice surprise.. right across from the courthouse, good sandwich selection, friendly staff, spacious seating and clean.
author: Sandra M.

description: Ordered the chicken sandwich, the chicken was obviously not fresh and microwaved. Was chewy and inedible.
author: Ohad A.

description:
Closest eatery place for a juror to land in.
Hoping to relax with a good mouth watery lunch.
Started out not friendly at all the moment I stepped in.
Freakin cold and hard rock sandwich for $10.06
Next time I'll bring my own frozen sandwich, probably taste better than that!
author: Judy T.

description:
This small local chain has locations in North Beach and Millbrae. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/caffe-roma-coffee-roasting-san-francisco?select=yy6g79gkKy3OzxWZRP8f3Q#yy6g79gkKy3OzxWZRP8f3Q I think people come here because there's nothing better. It's clean, service is okay, and the space looks decent. But everything is expensive, and food quality is only average (my opinion). I wish there was a Starbucks, Tully's, Peet's or Blue Bottle coffee instead.

Supposedly WiFi is free, but I've never got a valid signal on my PDA.
author: Luis C.

description: You lost a customer today. I will never be back. I paid for a sandwich before 9 am because I had an appointment. It was important that I was not late. I triple checked the time to pick it up. I was even later than I said and it still was not ready even though nobody was in line and it was before the lunch rush. I will never be back. You let me down when I asked for just one simple thing. Now I do not have time for lunch because they forgot about it. Thank you for absolutely nothing. And yes I was late because I waiting for a sandwich that was not made and the lied to me about it. I was told by one person they were wrapping it up but after waiting 5 minutes another told me that they did not make it and was working on it now. I asked for my money back and left.
author: Asia K.

description:
overpriced, but probably the only acceptable spot to get coffee whilst doing your civic duty. ugh, the wretchedness of jury duty. 

cards accepted but minimum $5. this is easy since a damn Anthony's cookie is $2.50 and a cappuccino will cost you about the same, if not a bit more. 

lots of light, free WiFi, and clean. the crackheads stay outta this joint. (they're probably all in McDs)
author: Susy C.

description: Lovely, large cafe in SOMA.  Pleasant, helpful staff.  Great coffee.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Jury duty was being a drag and I was hoping to make the most out of my break. Read some awesome reviews about this place and decided to give it a shot. It was super clean and nice inside, a real good environment as compared to what's in between here and the Hall of Justice across the street. So 1 star for that.

Another star for the friendly woman behind the counter who was patient while I decided what to get. I went simple and asked for an iced vanilla latte. Unfortunately they ran out of vanilla so she offered alternatives. I saw Hazelnut and thought hey, that should be good.

The first few sips weren't bad, I actually thought I liked it. But after maybe 4-5 sips it was disgusting! The hazelnut syrup tasted almost metallic-y and did not settle nicely in my mouth. It was making me gag and I immediately threw it away. Not sure what went wrong! :( as over exaggerated as it sounds, it was terrible.
author: Theresa F.

description: This is the closest cafe to my office and they definitely come in clutch when I need a coffee and starbucks in 3 blocks away. I can't wait to try some of their more interesting drinks (like the nutella latte!) I haven't had much of their food yet either but probably will soon. The prices are a little high but with the court house next door business doesn't seem to be a problem.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Brought my car to Bryant St and it was expected to take longer than I thought. A couple hours! So I had no where to go with nothing to do. I'm glad I randomly chose to chill here. Small white peppermint hot chocolate (I'm not a big coffee fan but I'm into holiday drinks) for $3.15. Nice, hot, and calming. Plus public wifi (from the Hall of Justice across the street, I'm guessing) which is perfect. I can't complain. Much more comfortable than walking around in the cold going no where.
author: Amanda L.

description: I walked in at noon and stood by a counter behind one other person, probably 5 people behind the counter rushing around getting ready for lunch hour so I waited patiently. While waiting another 5 minutes 20 people got in line behind me. A guy behind the sandwich bar started asking random people in line what sandwich they wanted, but he was too far down and the noise was too high for me to shout. The lady on front if me commiserated that the setup was confusing after neither of us were acknowledged for another few minutes. Then, order seemed to take place, she finally was assisted with a pick-up order, then I went to put in an order and was told to go all the way to the back to place an order. The guy knew his request was ridiculous- he could obviously take my order and he knew that I was skipped somehow but he was unrelenting. Made no sense & I was frustrated so I left.
author: Charlotte H.

description: Bad customer service. I ordered a panini sandwich and apparently I missed a step in the process of telling the people at the first counter what I want and went onto the next counter to pay. I did realize something was wrong when my order didn't came up after 10 minutes when all of my friends orders came out and probably another 10 sandwiches came out for the other customers ordering at that time. I made the server aware of the situation and he told me he's speeding up the process and my order will come out soon. THIRTY minutes have passed and my order didn't come out and the cashier gave me an attitude and told me that I just have to wait because it was my fault that I didn't tell the first counter what I wanted. He then offered me a refund. After waiting for 40 minutes???? He could have been apologetic but he was not and he felt he has the right to tell me that I was wrong... Never eating at this restaurant again. Ever.
author: Emmanuel M.

description:
Decent food poor service. 
Ordered a vegetarian sandwich with side salad. The sandwich was so so and the side salad provided much confusion for the staff resulting in me having to request it much later as it never came. For $13 I would happily spend my money elsewhere. For a quick coffee it will work, but a nice lunch? No.
author: Dane H.

description:
How do you mess up a Latte?  Ask Caffe Roma.  
$10 for 2 coffees and a slimy foot salad?  Avoid!
author: M S.

description: This is a nice place to have your coffee, but they never open on time. They are supposed to be open at 6am. I got be at work around 6:30am,  its already 6:20 and the doors are still closed.
author: Eddie L.

description:
The coffee is just alright... 

I might just have a super sweet tooth but I had to put 3 packets of sugar into my mocha to make it taste right.
author: Earlene C.

description:
I started coming in to the cafe to get coffee on my way to work every morning about a month ago. I started going primarily because they have almond milk that I can put in my latte or coffees. At first I really liked the place, but then I realized how RUDE the employees are. The two guys that work there every weekday morning are the worst. I tried so many times to be extra peppy and polite and to do things like ask how they were doing or say "hope you have a good day! I really appreciate it" but I just got scowls and grunts back. They half ass everything basically throw their drinks at you. You can tell they hate their job and that bothers me because it's not like I MADE you work here. I hope their employers and they both personally read this because they are extremely unpleasant and should not be allowed to work there. 

I decided today that I would rather go far out of my way to get a coffee then to encounter them in the morning.

Oh yeah, NEVER get one of their raw smoothies: it was DISGUSTING!!!!!!!
author: Kaitlyn N.

description:
pricey lunch, solid drinks

only for those who work in the area
author: Long C.

description: came here on a Sunday around the afternoon time and ordered this pizza type thing with scrambled eggs on top with some cheese. i can't recall why I chose that one but my stomach was pretty stoked and my hangover dissipated. haven't tried the coffee but I'm sure it would have paired well with my meal
author: Laurie M.

description:
Sort of yeah.

America! www.youtube.com/watch?v=YZdJRDpLHbw

Americana! Ham, apple chutney, caramelized onions, brie and spinach on a roll.

Unless you ask for turkey, caramelized onions and spinach on wheat bread.

Appreciated the customization. Too bad they were out of the chutney and hummus. Mostly my fault for a 3pm lunch. Gentleman helping me couldn't have been nicer.

Ginger cookie was a delicious snap. But also overpriced at $3.

WiFi worked in fits and starts.

Four stars for some things (service and sandwich potential), two stars for others (cookie pricing and WiFi). Sort of deserves three.
author: Jason B.

description: good place to just chill and get an evening coffee
author: Priyanka K.

description:
Went to Caffe Roma several times while serving on a jury last week. The sandwiches are really good, the coffee was fresh, place is clean, and the service was excellent. They have a little Belgium waffle-cookie-thing that is so tasty I went back for another. 

It would not be outstanding in a different neighborhood, but since it is the only decent place near the Hall of Justice, I give it a big thumbs up.
author: Erica G.

description: Not as busy as most coffee places but still good quality.  Serves snacks and Anthony's cookies sometimes too!
author: Allie B.

description: Paid $13 for a "shrimp and lentil" salad. It was a bowl of spring mix with maybe a quarter cup of lentils on top. And, oh yeah, almost forgot, FIVE. tiny. shrimp. ....thirteen bucks. Enough said.
author: Chloe D.

description:
The only conceivable explanation for the continued existence of this business is its proximity to 850 Bryant and the fact that most people who do business there run on hectic schedules which allow little time to wander far for a bite to eat.

If I were being charitable, I would describe their customer service as "inept." Walk in between 12:05 and 12:30, and there will likely be a line to the door. (They start breaking down the lunch cooler by about 12:35, so if you are a later luncher, be ready for scraps.) You will notice that the line moves at a snail's pace, for generally there is but a single employee taking and preparing lunch orders. There is also but a single register by which to process payment. Customers who are there only for coffee merge into the lunch line between the salad cooler and the register, so don't think your mind is playing tricks on you if you feel yourself moving further back in line rather than moving forward. It's actually happening. When you finally get to place your order, don't be surprised if they are out of the soup you planned on ordering. They will not do you the courtesy of erasing it from the menu board when the supply is depleted.

Their salads seem to be assembled with eye toward using up whatever random ingredients they having lying around, rather than with conscious consideration of what ingredients best compliment each other. Salads and pasta are available in three sizes: squat, small, and large. You'll notice there are containers demonstrating the sizes displayed behind the counter; you'll also notice there is absolutely no indication of price for any of the sizes. I have paid as little as $2.95 and as much as $5.75 for a squat of salad. There seems to be no consistent logic to how the price determinations are made; regardless of how much you pay for it, chances are that your salad will be salty or your pasta will be overcooked. On the several instances where I have raised the issue of this discrepancy at the register, I was admonished that different salads have different prices, and was generally made to feel a petty cheapskate. 


But perhaps that is to be expected, as Caffe Roma evidently runs on a "petty cheapskate" business model. I've noticed that of late, they process your order as "eat-in" (it displays these words on the register, visible to the customer) even when your food is visibly packaged to go. I don't know if they are pocketing the "sales tax" or what, but given the lack of transparency in their general pricing scheme, I wouldn't be surprised. Additionally, for about six months, they had a buy-ten-cups-of-coffee-get-one-free club, but apparently the goodwill this engendered within their core customer base did not mitigate the deep fiscal hit caused by giving away all those free coffees, and the club was unceremoniously disbanded.

The coffee is fine, though sometimes burnt.

Overall, their service is infuriatingly inefficient, and, on their best days, the food is mediocre and overpriced. You would be well-advised to go to Deli Deleon, McDonald's or Subway instead.
author: Alexandra P.

description: I always go here for my morning coffee before court at the hall of justice and I'm a coffee freak!  Best coffee shop in the neighborhood and even has clean restroom for customers. Just ask for the key!  Did I mention that the lunch and food are all fresh and really hit the spot!
author: Nors D.

description:
Came here only because I'm new to North Beach, and now I know to not come back.  Ordered a large iced coffee + tiramisu and the bill came to $10!  Fine, I'll happily pay premium for great dessert and a nice cup of coffee...but the coffee was undrinkable.  Tiramisu was alright, but not worth whatever price it was.  Seems like the other reviewers had more luck with their espresso drinks, so stick to that if you must dine here.  

Clean bathroom, plentiful seating, fair amount of outlets and free wifi wins this place 2 stars.  But what's a coffee shop without decent coffee?
author: Jenny Q.

description:
Jury Duty: Civic Duty or pain in the ass?

If there's any redemption, Caffe Roma carries the best Chocolate Cream Cheese and Pumpkin Cream Cheese Cupcakes (they may get them from The Ultimate Cookie).

As for the food, decent but pricey.  The sandwiches and salads are pretty good.  The pasta can be good but is usually mediocre.  I'd stick to the cupcakes.

How to get out of jury duty via Homer Simpson:
The trick is to say you're prejudiced against all races.

Now if I just had enough liquid courage to say that.
author: Dan B.

description:
Matt comes to this Caffe Roma often, because his workplace is around the corner. If you want a cup of coffee, you can't beat that for convenience. He'll be here for the next few weeks. 

The Monday crowd at 6:30 am was very busy with neighborring workers from the SoMa area. The big coffee-shop had a long line reaching towards the main-entrance. When it's Matt's turn, he order his usual Depth-charge, and a couple of other drinks to pickup for his associates. Matt's "strong" Depth Charge was tasty and aromatic, just like the North Beach shop. 

When Matt used to work  in the area, he would buy a pound of the popular "Frankie and Tony's" Blend and make them at his cubicle . The bean is very tasty and is Matt's favorite. Unfortunately when Matt leaves the coffee bean at work, it is gone by the next day. My co-worker will drink fresh coffee from anywhere, other than the Canned Coffee.
author: Matt G.

description:
+5 stars for the coffee and the barista
-3 stars for the sandwich maker counter server

I get my morning coffee here, the beans for my home and a few times I have ordered a bagel with just butter to go. This morning I asked if they could put the butter on the toasted bagel instead of the usual couple of butter chips in the bag. That way the butter would melt. Paid for my coffee and bagel and dropped a 1.50 tip in the jar.

As I stood waiting for 15 minutes I noticed my bagel sitting on the counter while the sandwich guy competed a bunch of other orders. I politely asked him how my bagel was coming along and he replied that is was "behind some other orders". I was surprised as of all the people in there I had been there the longest. Apparently they had gotten some phone orders while I was there and he was doing those first while my bagel sat getting cold. I asked if he could just put the butter on it as I was now late for work and he said he had to complete the to go orders first. I then asked him to bag my bagel "as is" without the butter and he replied, "if you want a special order you have to wait longer for it" Really, how long does it take to spread a little butter on a bagel and how long should one be expected to wait for it? No apology for the wait, nothing. It's now 20+ minutes for a bagel with butter.

Kinda wanted my tip back after that...
author: Am A.

description:
The decaf is terrible and they charge extra for it. Over $4 for a carmel latte? Sheesh. 

The Wifi doesn't work on my Mac. I asked around - another lady there with a Mac says she's been coming there for a while and has *never* been able to get on. 

Service is good and the bathrooms are very clean.

Meh. I've experienced better.
author: Tim W.

description: Coffee was epic, workers are kind and very nice. I love stepping into this cafe for coffee. The ambiance is very welcoming, even with the location being in a busy area. Roma is a place that I tell all my friends to try whenever in that area. I personally feel the coffee to be rich in flavor and definitely gives me that push for the morning work. Overall I had an excellent experience, I would likely recommend this place.
author: Ant J.

description:
We get a lot more out-of-town and/or too-drunk-to-drive houseguests since we moved to SF, and with that has come a drastically increased demand for coffee in the morning.  In fact, my parents bought a coffee maker on one visit as a "gift" to me.  But really it was so I could bring them coffee in bed instead of shipping them off to Starbucks.

But of course, a coffee-maker isn't enough; you also need top-quality coffee grounds to get those sleepy peeps out of bed.  So when my Cost Plus supply ran out (it came free with my coffee table--how cute), I started looking for a serious bean supplier.  Enter Caffe Roma--it's a North Beach institution, but the important thing is that they've also got a location on Bryant, near my work.  In addition to the gourmet beans (about $12 a pound, and worth it), it's also a great lunch spot.  Indeed, I'm really surprised there's not a huge lunch rush from the courthouse.  But it's actually quite peaceful, and the perfect place to enjoy a latte and a delicious (albeit slightly small) toasted sandwich.
author: Wes M.

description:
I initially gave Roma 2 stars, but after paying this cafe several visits, I have upgraded it to 3 stars. Yes it is overpriced ($8 for a sandwich!) but the service is excellent. The workers are always so friendly, which is nice to perk up my sleepy self in the morning.

The vanilla lattes are also getting tastier and tastier! :)
author: Christine A.

description: Must try the Nutella latte, for all those Nutella fans! Fast service, great place to people watch and nothing beats free wifi. Beware of cops, right across the street from the justice hall .
author: Reliford B.

description:
Cute cafe that if I was closer would frequent more often. Got a "regular, caffinated coffee" there this morning. Don't know what the girl poured but it was $1.95 for a large. Small is $1.75. Good coffee taste in the Italian style & served hot. 

Although I didn't have anything to eat, I asked about the selections. All pastries, muffins & desserts are brought in but the breakfast burritos & other hot food items are made in-house.

Across the street from the SF traffic & other violations building so easy to grab a coffee before you go stand in a line of some sort. 

Not sure if they use it but the roasting machines are set up behind the counter & on full display. Other Italian pictures & memorabilia on the walls & counters.
author: Marissa H.

description:
*******CENSORED REVIEW*******

The service behind the counter is surly and slow. 

The house coffee is caffeinated crap.
author: Monocle A.

description:
Roaming area (after REI purchase).
Needed a caffeine-fix.
Yelped and this place popped up.
Ordered a large house coffee straight-up.
It was just "aiight".
I got this coffee to-go...
Nice spacious place...
Gonna try their paninis next time...
author: Derek N.

description: I found it while walking home from doing an errand and thought, ' why not'?  the non-fat latte was excellent,  and the service was also excellent..
author: Carl C.

description:
I really don't understand how this place could have so many stars. The coffee is horrendous. I used to go here all the time since they offered free WiFi and after trying what I have found to be the worst coffee I have ever experienced, I felt compelled to try it again on my second visit thinking something had to be horribly wrong the first time. 

Nope, I was right the first time only this time it was far far worst. Holy crap is it bad coffee. Looking around the space makes me sad since they have such an awesome roasting room with beautiful equipment. If only they could learn how to roast their coffee. Even after experiencing the worst coffee I have ever tasted I would STILL go here and order a cup of tea (and once a breakfast burrito which could of been better if it wasn't cold). After awhile I found that the WiFi I was using (which wasn't even Cafe Roma's) had gone down. When I couldn't connect to Cafe Roma's WiFi I spoke to one of the employees there who said they would take a look at it but it should be working. I found a new place to work from in the mornings for two months and finally went again today only to find that the WiFi still isn't working.
author: Ericka A.

description: Good Place to chill and get some coffee outside of the Hall of Justice.
author: Victoria L.

description: The only good coffee shop outside of the Hall of Justice, they know it and they charge their customers accordingly. Came here once when I was volunteering here and bought what should had been a cup of blue moon.
author: M C.

description: Coffee most hideous and disgusting.  I can't believe it, I really cannot.
author: G J J.

description: Lots of cocoa powder lumps in my iced mocha, but good coffee. Great breakfast burrito. Eggs, cheese, salsa, sliced ham. Layered instead of piled in. And just enough to satisfy. I don't like my breakfasts super-sized, and do not enjoy a burrito the size of a brontosaurus burger.
author: Michele W.

description: Delicious mocha while waiting for my car to be serviced! I couldn't get the wi-fi to work, but I appreciated the abundance of tables :)
author: Lana L.

description:
Caffe Roma is the only restaurant I've tried around the Hall of Justice that would survive downtown.  It's an upscale cafeteria with a changing array of interesting salads, freshly-made sandwiches, and deserts.  

It's no destination spot, but after a grotty morning in the jury box, Caffe Roma is a welcome reminder that there is civilization out there.
author: Galen W.

description:
Across from the Hall of Justice, this place is a different animal from the other food options around.  It's a little bit "classier" and a little bit "cleaner."  It has table and chairs and a seating area filled with natural light.  There are uncluttered chilled food displays that offer up fantastic looking pastries and lively salads.  The espresso drinks are made fresh to order and even the iced tea tastes decent to Asian taste buds.  

The menu has sandwiches and there are lunch combos that include salads and soups.  it's served on real plates and eaten with real cutlery.  When you order an eclair to go, they'll put it in a specialized container rather than dumping it in a paper bag.  The people here are friendly and efficient without being hurried.  They take credit cards.

Downside: it's more expensive.  Maybe it's designed to keep out the riffraff like me.  Maybe it's because natural light costs more per square feet on Bryant St.  For instance, a can of diet coke costs $1.50.  I guess it boils down to how much you're willing to pay to maintain your classy status.
author: Christina C.

description:
7-19-07 Pretty accessible, although not as tastey as StarBZ.  It does get my fix though. 4Stars

9-11-07 Warning -- TRAGIC!
I have to modify my review as to my most recent experience with Caffe Roma just 10 minutes ago at 11:45am today.  I was already almost half way through my coffee when my next sip turned out to be something quite disgusting -- I'm shivering with disgust as I write this.  Included with that sip was 97% the body of a FLY.  the remaining 3% was a leg left over floating on the suface of the drink which I saw when I opened the lid.  Needless to say I will NEVER go there EVER again.  Also, I will tell as many people my experience so they can make the best decision when buying coffee from Caffe Roma.  BTW, I took pictures of the fly I spit out along with the leftover leg floating on the top of my drink.  MSG me if you want to see.  GROSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS.
author: Michael B.

description:
This was a gem in the rough over on Bryant St while I was getting a window replaced in my car at Glass Pro (because of a typical SF break-in).

Anyway, I had my laptop with me and I was able to use their free wireless internet while enjoying a delightful cup of Island Cherry Green Tea. Yum. 
Also, the guys working there were pleasantly kind.  

Good place to go to if life brings you into the courthouse, police station, or Glass Pro.  It might make you feel better :)
author: Amy J.

description:
Really good sandwiches, salads, pasta, and AMAZING desserts.

I'm not a fan of the coffee here.  Granted I'm not a big coffee drinker.  More of a latte girl myself.  This latte was warm and bitter.  Bleh.  

The help is very inconsistant here too.  They may stare at you for a long time before asking if you need any help.  If it gets a little busy it's the worst, they never help who's next in line, but more like whoever is closest to them.  There always seems to be confusion at the register regarding prices of things, which isn't comforting either.  All in all, they really need to streamline their system.  Which seems to be currently nonexistent.

Really good cheap food though!  With a spacious interior, excellent for studying or relaxing on lunch breaks.
author: Mary R.

description:
Thank God for this place!

Jury Duty is pure hell - we all know this. But everyone leaving for lunch at the same time? That can be hell too. (Including Ed Jew - who got in my elevator - yeah, that was me. On the news. In the corner of the elevator)

Caffe Roma is across the street and NOT crappy - which it could be, since it is the closest place to the Courthouse. The service was fast. The food was fresh. I had a GREAT turkey and brie pannini-like sandwich with a side of cous cous. You get free chips with a sandwich.

They have great looking deli salads and pastas. A lot of people were ordering salad but when I am miserable the last thing I want is rabbit food. They also have free wireless - too bad it wasn't working when I was there (-1). There is a lot of seating and nice bar seats for the loners from jury duty. In the morning when I walked by there was a long line for coffee and snacks - I would definitely go back here if I am in the area!
author: Jessica L.

description: I stopped in yesterday for a Latte... it was fantastic! I love the feel of the cafe. It was unique to seem them roasting the coffee right there.
author: Kathryn G.

description:
Cafe Roma needs to change it''s name to 'Cafe Roma in SOMA.' :) And then do some serious advertising to us locals in a 4 block radius.

I seriously did a double take finding this little gem in the heart of SOMA and can't believe I have a new place I can do my studies and work as an alternative to Border's on 3rd.  THANKS CAFE ROMA for extending your branches from North Beach!!! You are a blessing....
author: Yelper A.

description:
5 Stars for the Service and Food!  

Special props to Irene and Frankie!  Irene has the MOST AMAZING memory and will remember almost everyone BY NAME if introduced or just by credit card.  The Staff there ROCKS and it makes the food that much better.  Great friendly environment.  

Yeah, ok, this restaurant caters to the HOJ crowd across the street.  The food is good and always fresh.  $8 for a sandwich is TYPICAL for SOMA so come on people --its San Francisco not Billings Montana!  The salads are always fresh as are the pastries and danish.

LOVE LOVE LOVE the coffee.  So much more flavor and depth than the chain coffee houses.  Yup, I do support local businesses and try not to do the Peets or Starbucks which are just a few blocks down the road. And they roast their coffee on premises.  What more can you ask for?  Oh yeah-- Free Wifi!  

Oh, and their Cream of Mushroom Soup is out of this world!
author: tony g.

description:
Never mind the fact that I have known the Azzollini family for years, perhaps that fact I have done the weddings of the Azzollini "kids"; Irene, Tony and Lisa might make me just a wee bit biased, but the coffee is still the best darn coffee in the city.

Perfectly roasted in house, and blended from the finest beans, no matter what you get, drip, espresso, latte, mocha, whatever, consistency reigns supreme. My favorite is a rich, full bodied light/dark blend called, Via Vento. Go there for lunch for housemade salads and sandwiches and desserts like cannoli and Tiramisu, which is wonderful. The cafe is always hopping, as it  is a prime spot for the workers who slave away at the Hall o' Justice.

Expect the good old-fashioned service that you would get from any family-owned and operated business, chances are you'll get served from Irene, Lisa or Dino, the owners whom are as charming as they are engaging.

So if your taste buds haven't  been totally destroyed by the likes of Starbucks, try Cafe Roma for some real coffee. The North Beach location run by Tony, is great too!
author: Candace W.

description:
Sigh. Jury duty again. What can you do? On my slog from Bart through SOMA to get to the courthouse, I consoled myself with the idea that maybe, if I was lucky, I'd find a coffee shop where I could get a little inspiration for sitting in a room for hours with my fellow citizens, also doing their civic duty. When I actually saw Caffe Roma I almost didn't notice it, what with its prime location in the middle of about forty-seven bail bonds joints. When I went in, the place was jammed, but they were super friendly; the woman who gave me my iced coffee even melted some sugar for me when I asked if they had any simple syrup. (The coffee was great.)

The next day, alas, I was back at jury duty, and when I went in for lunch (excellent salami sandwich) the woman (owner?) working at the register  remembered my name, which she had gotten just from seeing my credit card the day before. Pretty cool, I must say. I'm a big fan of this place; if I have to go back to jury duty (or if, say, I ever need a bail bond) I'll definitely be back.
author: Caroline G.

description:
I love my bagel and coffee.  These are by far the best bagels around!  The lunches are also excellent and always fresh.  Service is alwasy friendly and easy.
Wouldn't mind some organic eggs though.
author: elizabeth m.

description: The most gorgeous barista works here now....Ladies leave your man at home... I SAID GODDAMN.
author: Sancho P.

description:
Everytime the weather gets ugly I always have a craving for soup. So I'll walk over here during my lunch break to have a nice cup of soup of the day while reading the newspaper and people watching. I've been pretty satisfied with every soup I've tried. Before you would never find me ordering chicken noodle soup because it reminds me of being sick in bed and eating crappy soup from the can. But this place changed all that.

Thank you Caffe Roma for exposing me to hearty chicken noodle soup.
author: Victoria N.

description:
Solid 4 stars. Had the Proscuitto and Mozarella sandwich. Came with pickle and chips. It was fantabulous. Ordered a raspberry italian soda, which had a whole lot of syrup in it. Mm Torani. I think I over raspberried at lunch.

Damn that sangwich was good.
author: Annie T.

description:
I've always tried to steer clear of any dining establishments that are directly across from the city jail, but then I thought about it...and you find way more office workers than street workers in Roma's.
I stop by frequently when I've decided to opt out of the bike lane on Folsom & take a ride on the wild side, aka Bryant Street in the mornings on my route to work.
They have some tasty pastries and their bagels aren't too horrible, they need to be told to toast them brown though. They offer fruit parfaits, which are my favorite breakfast treat, but here they use oatmeal instead of a nice crunchy granola, so not too stoked on that. Being a tea gal, I can only speak to the nice selection of reasonably priced juices offered at this cafe since that's what I get to go with my grub in the morning.
All in all a nice (and expansive) cafe, located on a strange block.
author: Colleen B.

description: I had the vanilla latte . It was awesome! Rich , flavorful & oh so creamy. Nice , friendly service. And the heart they made in the foam was a cute touch. - Made me smile on a really lousy morning. I'm definetely coming back.
author: Irene K.

description:
Friday, working at home, needed food. walked over there and stared at the menu. yup,. really needed food. everyone was nice and patient (pre lunch time rush). picked a sandwich and walked home. stepped away from said sandwich and returned to find bad dog opening the wrapper and trying to get to my sandwich. ha! yelled at bad dog, took my sandwich back.
bad dog was smart. this grilled chicken sandwich was tasty. carmelized onions, cheese, tasty chicken, good bread. crunchy pickle (minus the bad dog's hair). even got surprised by the bag of chips.
mental note to remember this place when i'm too stupid to remember i need to eat. wish it was open on weekends. 
wow. good sandwich. did i mention that? had really nice looking cookes and pastries, too.
author: Margie L.

description: Generally the best coffee on the block.  They roast their own on site.  Nice sitting area too.  Lunch selections are generally tasty, but not cheap.  If you want to overhear the buzz from the cops and lawyers from 850, come here and chill at lunchtime.
author: Stephen F.

description:
They seem nice to their regulars, but since I wasn't a regular, they were not so nice.  They have a menu for their coffee up on the wall, but where's their sandwich/food menu?  Oh, it's a tiny sheet of paper next to the counter, and no one tells you this until you ask them for help after standing there trying to find the menu for a few minutes.
i order my sandwich, and he asked me what kind of bread, but I didn't look at the menu for my choices, I guess this is my fault, so I didn't know.  He rudely lists the breads off, and tried to explain what the different types of breads were.  I'm not stupid, I know what ciabatta and wheat are.

Anyways, my sandwich was sitting there for five minutes, just sitting there, until someone bags it and leaves it there for another five minutes.  after waiting an extra ten minutes for my sandwich they call out really quietly, "Vegetarian sandwich to go,"  and they had secretly stuck in a bag of Lays classic potato chips.  If there is anything I hate more than cafe roma, it is Lays classic potato chips.  Ugh.

Oh, and the cost of a sandwich is $7.50, which I think is pretty pricey.
author: H. L.

description:
The go-to place for people who do business at the Hall of Justice. Think judges, district attorneys, public defenders, private criminal defense attorneys, cops, jurors. 

The people who own the joint are extremely friendly and know all the regulars by name. The coffee is good and strong and I love a place that does its own coffee bean roasting. The food is average at best and definitely overpriced but this place can get away with it because of the lack of dining choices in the area.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Cafe Roma is literally one block away from my house - I love it!  The coffee is superb, and so far the few food items I have tried were delicious.  It is so nice to walk there in the mornings and have a friendly person start my morning with a perfect latte and a smile.
My only complaint is that they are not open on the weekends!  I know that they mostly cater to the attorneys and that crowd, but this neighborhood is growing and needs excellent options for eats and non-Starbucks coffee.
author: Joanna C.

description:
After coming here to the US, we'd only seen the chain brands of coffee, which are as weak as water. I figured little Italy would be the home of some real coffee, and after a quick net search, voila!
These guys do some nice black roasts, and will grind it to suit percolators, cap. machines, etc. 
I've only tried the Sicilian Gold, and it is intensely strong.
A nice change from Homer Simpson sized cups of Starbucks rubbish!
author: Ed R.

description:
I have worked three blocks from here for the last two years and just stumbled upon it thanks to the SFPD. (Ok it's my fault). I love this place the food is great and the coffee has replaced my old favorite of Soma Caf on Howard, where I used to next too. Ok maybe not totally. I still sneak over there now and then, that coffee is jet fuel. 
The staff including the owners are the nicest around and always shows their appreciation. Great salads, creative sandwiches there probably getting sick of seeing me.
author: Cathy M.

description:
I actually send 5LB bags of their coffee beans to Massachusetts' family members! 

These are the friendliest people ! None of that corporate hullabaloo going on here...

The coffee is traditional house roasted italian brews. Dark, smooth and not a bit bitter!
Their sandwiches and salads are home -made and tasty.

Keep on rocking!
author: tery c.

description: I really appreciate this coffee shop!  It's right around the corner from my internship/work place and it definitely is good for those quick jolts of caffeine!  Yup, definitely never ceases to fail me when I have one of those sluggish mornings.  The coffee gets me jittery and through the workday LOL which means it's pretty good strong coffee if you ask me--not your typical over priced Starbucks that's for sure!  My boss and I have gotten Taco Salads/Tostada Salads here and they are surprisingly really really good! A bit pricey but honestly most of the food places in front of the justice center are pretty pricey anyway!
author: Mary-Anne C.

description:
Frankie roasts the best coffee.   We used to purchase and serve his  coffee in our cafe "Cafe Society"  in Napa.     Everyone commented on the quality. 
Thanks Frankie.
author: steve o.

description: Cute, and clean and a great alternative for me as a food option in the area since there aren't many places in that I can walk to from my work for a quick bite to eat. Coffee and coffee drinks, salads, and sandwiches, and desserts and pastries. Pretty good variety and selection of everything, which increases the likelihood that when you come in here you'll find something you will want to eat or drink. Never overly busy, but that to me is good. It's also never empty.
author: Denise B.

description: I actually really like the coffee here, I just wish they weren't so needlessly unfriendly.  The youngish guy who always takes my order never says hello, thank you, or anything.  He doesn't make eye contact and throws the change back on the counter.  WTF?
author: Geoffrey U.

description: Still here ...still going strong.  Back when this location first opened I used to work at 850 Bryant (the jail house) and went here for lunch 3 to 4 times a week. They still serve great sandwiches and the coffee which by the way is roasted on site is outstanding. It is a family operated coffee roasters and cafe which also adds to the charm. I still crave the Caprese  sandwich so every once in a while just like today I go by and grab one.
author: Teddy d.

description:
I spent an hour here waiting for my car to be repaired in the nearby shop. 

Ordered cafe latte. It was excellent. They have free wifi too.

One complaint - I hate big screen TVs at the restaurants and cafes. They have at least 4 all around...
author: eugene i.

description:
Caffe Roma plays perhaps too large a role in my life.

As many of the reviews state, there aren't many lunchtime options in SOMA.  I work across the street, and this is by far the best place to get food.

The Good:
1. BEST Ice Tea ever.  I love it.  And the lemonade is good, too.
2. The soups are delicious.  They now have tomato bisque twice a week, due to popular demand.
3. The desserts are so good.  They have these seasonal butter / sugar cookies that rival the ones I bake.  And they're gigantic - I pick one up and share it with three co-workers, and all of our sugar cravings are fixed.
4. The chicken pesto sandwich!  It's BIG (all their sandwiches are) and flavorful.  I can't eat a whole one, so I usually split one with a co-worker.
5. HAMBURGER TUESDAYS!  Burger options in the 'hood are thin on the ground.  One of the deputies turned me on to the burgers... The cops and deputies line up for them weekly.
6. If you're a regular (which, apparently, I am), the staff and owners typically know your name and "the usual."  It's nice to have that level of personal service.
7. The owners really are the best.  They care about their customers and work hard at customer service.
8. The food is always fresh and there's always a good variety of salads.

The Bad:
1. It's expensive.  The quality is excellent, but a $12 take-out lunch bill can make a dent in the wallet.  Still, you get what you pay for... there is no comparable sandwich or soup in the neighborhood.
2. There can be errors in orders...  I once ordered a tostada with no beans, and instead got one with plenty of beans and no chicken.  I once ordered a chicken wrap and was given a crab wrap (no thanks, no crabs for me!).  Alas, if the owners are there, they'll always do their best to right any wrongs, and they're sincere in wanting to please their customers.  I think that's more important than getting it right all the time.
3. They sometimes run out of things.  Some days see mad rushes, other days are quiter around the Hall of Justice.  It just depends.

All in all, if you're anywhere near the Hall of Justice and are in need of some good fare, you will be pleasantly surprised by this place.  It's my favorite lunch place and I'm there several times a week.  It's popular with the cops and the deputies for a reason.
author: Melanie K.

description: Caffe Roma has the best coffee in San Francisco.  I actually travel here once a month to buy three pounds of coffee.  I brew it at home every morning.  I also like that they give you a free latte or coffee when you buy a pound of coffee.  The only coffee that is better is in Paris!
author: Jane A.

description: Veronica make the most amazing coffee drinks... you need to check out her awesome style!!!!!
author: trixie a.

description: Decent food, salads. Staff needs some customer service 101, especially the young woman working the register. And who makes a salad w balsamic dressing in a mixing bowl that already has Caesar dressing in it? Is that not a food code violation? No one asked me what i'd like to drink, so I asked the cashier. Her exact words, "oh you need to be ready for me to charge you. I'm not gonna run around and get it for you.". I guess the fact that it's the only decent place by the court house means they don't have to be polite.
author: shelley p.

description: Close to my internship. I usually get my coffee here in the morning. The coffee is good, but it was pricey for the size. There's only one cashier counter, so the line and wait can get long. Their food is pricey too for their portions. Their bagels are on the small size. And the quality is decent.
author: Sam W.

description: Great coffee and sandwiches. A touch on the expensive side, but hey, you get what you pay for.
author: N O.

description: This is a good alternative to Peet's coffee. It gives me the same high.... Starbucks doesn't do anything for me if I need a pick me up. Peet's is not within walking distance so I go here. Tasty lattes and mochas. A little on the pricey side for lunch though. $8 for a sandwhich is a little steep... but $3 for a great tasting mocha is A-OK! The occasional Gavin sighting is worth while as well. :)
author: Kat L.

description: A favorite spot of mine for strong, creamy espresso and biscotti.
author: Juliane N.

description: Veronica is simple the best! Makes the perfect coffee drinks... no matter what I order!
author: christy c.

description: excellent service, nice ambiance.  at lunch time, you'll mostly find the attorneys from across the street.  i got an amazing salad with spinach, feta cheese, cranberries, and other veggies.  the viniagrette made it absolutely divine.  it is on the pricier side though.
author: Amy Z.

description: Picking Caffe Roma as your coffee destination can leave a bitter taste in one's mouth and it's not from bad beans but rather, Roma's utter lack of customer service.  After requesting a large cup with ice for my small coffee, I was informed I had to pay for the large coffee and then was educated in the costs of cups for 10 minutes by staff.  I had been on an anti-roma kick for about a week until today when I went in to give the place a second try.  This time I bought my small coffee @ $2.95 and when reached in for the beloved credit card, was told by the same employee that there was now a $3.00 min purchase.  I get minimum purchases, however this was 5 cents a way!  I called the owner myself this morning and told her my concerns.  I was told the $3.00 min purchase is a new policy that they just started, of course there is no signage in the store or at the register and was again educated on how expensive credit card transactions were with no sight of an apology.  Save the lectures on cost and go down the street to Caf De Leon or better yet McDonalds... you can pay for your coffee and actually get what you want.
author: sean m.

description: Superb coffee.  Tony and Frankie's is excellent.  I mail ordered it, and it came the next day.
author: John D.

description:
i love roma's espresso, it is among the best i have had in town. 

the food however is a bit pricey.
author: steven w.

description: when you do get coffee its good, when you dont it sucks but I take people there just to see the place, they dont always buy which means this opalkce would be great if someone bought it and made a decent job of it.
author: Razza M.
